David Saff wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
>  > not all specs are
>  > story-level specs, so I think the annotation @Story is misleading.
> 
> Any thoughts on another annotation?

I'm not sure. I don't think we've ever had a name for "low-level piece 
of behavior" as expressed in a test, except for the word "test". We 
could replace that with the other generic term "Specification" or 
"Expectation" or even, oddly enough, "Constraint", in the sense that 
each Constraint further constrains the space of codebases that can solve 
the problem we're working on.

>  > There's an interesting change afoot: maybe the @Story annotation should
>  > go on the class, and not on the method. Possibly @Story applies at a
>  > higher level. I don't know. If we don't think of them as tests for
>  > methods, then how do we organize them? (other than the obvious things
>  > we've been doing--put 'em in one class until that gets too big, then
>  > split based on fixture objects.)
> 
> Lately, I've been using full sentences as the names of my test classes
> and test methods.  The method names are the sentences in a paragraph,
> and the class name is the topic sentence:
> 
> PluginTestsRunCorrectlyOnJUnit4Projects
> 
> or, more prosaicly,
> 
> RemotePluginTestRunnerIsCorrect
> with methods:
>     correctPluginIsUsedToLoadRunner
>     testLoaderPluginIsUsedToLoadTestLoader
>     throwsExceptionIfTestPluginFlagNotGiven (hmm, that's not a
> sentence.  Very well then, I contradict myself.)
> 
> There's probably something more important to say as a topic sentence
> about RemotePluginTestRunner, but I haven't determined what it is yet.
> 
> I've been hoping, although it is yet to be seen, that my top-level suite:
> 
> public class UnitTests extends GenericMockObjectTestCase {
>     public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
>         TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>         suite.addTestSuite(PDEJUnitLaunchConfigurationIsCorrect.class);
>        
> suite.addTestSuite(JUnitLaunchShortcutFindsOnlyMatchingLaunchConfigurations.class);
>         suite.addTestSuite(JUnitLaunchConfigurationIsCorrect.class);
>         suite.addTestSuite(RemotePluginTestRunnerIsCorrect.class);
> 
> would eventually read like the high-level story of what my program does,
> if the classes are well named.  We shall see,

That is quite neat, although I find "IsCorrect" to be assumed in the 
context of the name of a test suite. We need a better name for 
"addTestSuite()".

suite.addTestSuiteFor(PDEJUnitLaunchConfiguration.class);
...

What's a little unnerving is that there might be a production class 
named PDEJUnitLaunchConfiguration, and I don't want people thinking 
we're writing one test case class per production code class--at least, 
not for ever.
